verses.text: For everything there is a fixed time, and a season for every purpose under heaven:
verses.comment: The Preacher affirms the sovereignty of God over time and all events. This affirms God's providence—a key theme throughout Scripture—and prefigures the unfolding of salvation history according to divine wisdom (see Rom. 8:28).

verses.text: a time to be born, and a time to die; a time to plant, and a time to uproot what is planted;
verses.comment: This verse marks the cycle of life and creation. It acknowledges both beginnings and endings, illustrating that human life is subject to God’s order.

verses.text: a time to kill, and a time to heal; a time to tear down, and a time to build up;
verses.comment: God allows for judgment as well as restoration. Healing and building up point to renewal and grace in God’s ongoing work with humanity.

verses.text: a time to weep, and a time to laugh; a time to mourn, and a time to dance;
verses.comment: Human emotions and experiences are part of God's plan. Spiritual life embraces both sorrow and joy, symbolizing the fullness of human experience sanctified by God, as Jesus Himself wept and rejoiced (John 11:35; Luke 10:21).

verses.text: a time to throw stones, and a time to gather stones together; a time to embrace, and a time to refrain from embracing;
verses.comment: Symbolic actions (throwing and gathering stones) refer to building, destroying, and reconciliation, as seen in God’s dealings with His people. Embrace signifies intimacy and fellowship, themes of both familial and spiritual unity.

verses.text: a time to seek, and a time to lose; a time to keep, and a time to throw away;
verses.comment: This evokes Christ’s parables concerning the lost and found, and it suggests detachment from earthly things, echoing Jesus’ teachings to store up treasures in heaven (Matt. 6:19-21).

verses.text: a time to tear, and a time to sew; a time to be silent, and a time to speak;
verses.comment: Tearing and sewing were associated with mourning and mending in ancient culture, as in the rending of garments (Joel 2:13). Silence and speech recall the wisdom of discerning the right word at the right time (James 1:19).

verses.text: a time to love, and a time to hate; a time for war, and a time for peace.
verses.comment: Love and hate here refer to choosing righteousness over evil; war and peace echo the Scriptures’ tension between conflict and the ultimate peace God desires (Isa. 2:4). Christ fulfills peace in Himself (Eph. 2:14).

verses.text: What gain has the worker from his toil?
verses.comment: A recurring question in Ecclesiastes—what is the lasting value of human labor? The answer is ultimately found in eternal things, not the fleeting pursuits of this world (Matt. 6:33).

verses.text: I have seen the burden God has given to the children of men to keep them occupied.
verses.comment: Human striving is part of God's providential plan, designed to awaken spiritual longing for something greater than the world can provide.

verses.text: He has made everything beautiful in its time. He has also put eternity in their hearts, yet man cannot find out what God has done from beginning to end.
verses.comment: This verse affirms both God’s sovereignty and the spiritual desire built into the human heart—a longing that can only be fulfilled in God Himself. This anticipates the fullness of revelation in Christ (John 17:3).

verses.text: I know that there is nothing better for them than to rejoice and to do good while they live.
verses.comment: God desires human happiness rooted in righteousness and charity. Doing good aligns with Jesus’ summary of the Law—love of God and neighbor (Matt. 22:37-40).

verses.text: And also, that everyone should eat and drink and take pleasure in all his toil—this is the gift of God.
verses.comment: Simple joys and the fruit of honest labor are blessings from God. This also signifies a spiritual gratitude for God’s daily provision.

verses.text: I know that everything God does will endure forever; nothing can be added to it, nor anything taken from it. God works so that people will stand in awe before Him.
verses.comment: The sovereignty and perfection of God's works create true reverence (‘fear of the Lord’). This is key to wisdom and points to the eternal nature of God’s covenant purposes (Heb. 13:20).

verses.text: That which is, already has been; that which is to be, already has been; and God seeks what has been driven away.
verses.comment: History is not outside God’s control; He restores what is lost—a foreshadowing of redemption and resurrection (Luke 19:10).

verses.text: Moreover, I saw under the sun that in the place of justice, wickedness was there, and in the place of righteousness, wickedness was there as well.
verses.comment: The reality of evil in this world does not undo God’s justice, which surpasses human justice and will ultimately prevail (Isa. 11:4).

verses.text: I said in my heart, 'God will judge the righteous and the wicked, for there is a time for every purpose and for every work.'
verses.comment: This points to the final judgment. Divine justice is ultimately assured, a theme central to Jesus’ teaching about the last judgment.

verses.text: I said in my heart regarding the sons of men that God tests them, so that they may see that they themselves are like animals.
verses.comment: God allows humankind to recognize their limitations and dependence on the Creator. Humility is the beginning of wisdom and faith.

verses.text: For what happens to the sons of men is the same as what happens to the beasts; as one dies, so dies the other. They all have the same breath, and man has no advantage over the beasts; for all is vanity.
verses.comment: Physical death appears to be the same for all creatures. This highlights the need for hope in a reality beyond death. The New Testament reveals resurrection through Christ (1 Cor. 15:22).

verses.text: All go to the same place; all are from the dust, and all return to the dust.
verses.comment: Echoing Genesis—human and beast alike return to dust. Yet, later revelation speaks of the resurrection of the body, completing what is hinted at here (Dan. 12:2).

verses.text: Who knows if the spirit of man goes upward and the spirit of the beast goes down into the earth?
verses.comment: A question that was mysterious for ancient Israel, yet is clarified by later revelation: humans are destined for spiritual eternity (Luke 23:43).

verses.text: So I saw that there is nothing better than that a man should rejoice in his work, for that is his lot. For who can bring him to see what will be after him?
verses.comment: Man is encouraged to accept the limits of human knowledge and enjoy God’s present gifts. Nevertheless, Christian faith teaches to hope in an inheritance beyond this life (1 Pet. 1:3-4).
